conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking all non-emergency notifications during work hours, while User Story B allows controlling notifications per client, which may include allowing some non-emergency notifications. They give opposite instructions on handling non-emergency notifications in overlapping contexts.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications for each client myself, so I can avoid overload and respect their wishes.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours, but User Story B wants to see notifications for each client clearly. These are opposite expectations about showing notifications in the same context, causing a conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see notifications for each client clearly, so I can care for them without getting mixed up or tired.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours (forbid operation), while User Story B wants to manually choose which notifications to see first (start operation) which may include non-emergency ones. Both impose opposite behaviors on the same notifications under overlapping conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose which client notifications to see first so I can handle my work without feeling too busy.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours, meaning the system should not send these notifications then. User Story B requires the caregiver to manually choose which alerts to acknowledge, implying all alerts are delivered first for manual selection. These two are opposite because one forbids non-emergency alerts during work hours while the other expects all alerts to be delivered for manual handling.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually choose which alerts to acknowledge for each client, so I can control my responses and not miss important messages.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours (forbid operation), while User Story B wants to control when notifications come during care tasks (start operation). Both require controlling notifications in overlapping contexts, creating opposite instructions for notification delivery.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when I get notifications during care tasks so I can focus on each client without interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours (forbid notifications), while User Story B wants to customize alert sounds for each client to recognize alerts (start notifications). Both relate to alert handling and conflict in whether non-emergency notifications should be allowed.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose alert sounds for each client to quickly know who needs help without looking.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-emergency notifications during work hours, implying urgent alerts continue. User Story B allows manual control over urgent alerts, which may include blocking them. These are opposite instructions for urgent alerts under the same conditions, causing conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually control urgent alerts for each client to respect their privacy and respond properly.

conflictDescription: User Story A blocks non-emergency notifications during work hours, while User Story B accepts all notifications at night but filters urgent ones. The conflicting conditions (work hours vs night) for handling notifications differ, making their operation triggers inconsistent.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to accept all notifications at night but choose which are urgent, so I can stay responsive without missing important alerts.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours, which forbids showing these notifications, while User Story B wants urgent needs to be shown clearly so the caregiver can act fast. These opposite expectations on showing notifications under the same conditions create a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver managing many clients, I want ALFRED to show urgent needs clearly so I can act fast without losing focus.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires blocking all non-emergency notifications during work hours, which forbids notifications at that time. User Story B requires following client wishes for interaction times, which may allow notifications during those times. Both impose opposite actions on notifications during overlapping time periods.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to follow clients' wishes for interaction times, so I do not disturb their daily routine.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-emergency notifications during work hours, while User Story B wants to allow clients to send social invitations (a type of notification) without a strict block. These are opposite requests about controlling notifications, causing a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when clients send social invitations, so I can manage my time and avoid feeling too busy.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours, but User Story B wants to receive all notifications including health and emotional alerts. These are opposite expectations about notification delivery under similar conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all notifications, including health updates and emotional prompts, so I can support my clients well.
